climbs.name: Wish You Were Here
climbs.fa: Shane Willet Paul Moore Mark Nakada 1998

content.description: Awesome climb with some exposure. Use the arete when in doubt. Amazing views from the top.
content.location: On the arete just right of Dont Tell Jonny.

content.description:
This is a new 5.11 direct start to Tequila. It avoids the crack start so you can now lead Tequila with quickdraws only. Follow the bolts directly up the nice face.

Features fun positive face climbing on edges up to a tricky face move to clip the 6th bolt (long draw or runner). Move right under roof to join with Tequila.

11 bolts plus anchor.
content.location: This is the direct, bolted start variation to Tequila. Follow bolted line on face leading to right side of roof.

content.description:
If this looks a little intimidating, it is, but its nothing a little Tequila won't take care of...

Climb a small and thin, broken crack system up and left towards a large roof. Aim for the middle of the roof and clip a bolt. Power, and I mean POWER through this crux to a steep and sequential face, save some juice for the tricky finish. Continuously steep and rather sustained, hop on this when you're fresh and feeling it. Agava Tequila optional, but recommended.

Long and out there.
content.protection: Bring a selection of mirco nuts and small cams/tcus and expect about 6 or seven bolts.
content.location:
On the right side of the

Moore Wall

,

Tequila

is the middle line marked by a bolt that climbs the middle face to the right/center of the roof.

content.description: Start on a ramp and climb left to a roof.  Figure out where to put your feet and crimp threw the roof to a nice rest stance.  Climbing past the next overlap is hard to read and consistent.  Getting to the anchor is pumpy but fun climbing.
content.location: Second route starting from the left on the Moore Wall

climbs.name: Paul's Route
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willet, Mark Nakada, summer 1998

content.description:
Paul's route is a good warm-up for the Moore Wall and a great introduction to the style of the area: long steep faces, crimpy horizontals and techy footwork.

Climb a blocky moderate start past 2 bolts to a ledge then tackle a perfect thin face past 11 more bolts. A detached pillar to the left provides relief when the moves start feeling tough for 5.9. The last 2 bolts force you on the face away from this feature for a full value finish.
content.protection:
13 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

Rap off the metolius hangers
content.location:
This route it the furthest left on the Moore Wall. It's the 3rd bolted line to the left of the giant dihedral. Look for a hanged at the lip of a triangular block, that's

Ray of Light

.

Paul's Route

is the next one to the left.

content.description:
A fun and striking corner,

The Passage

climbs the certain dihedral to the wall's upper rim. Despite a loose and dirty upper pitch, good moves through a good crack still make this a decent choice.

This is also the starting pitch for

Free Passage

.

P1:

Solid rock and good climbing pass a single crux and a piece of old tied off webbing. Finish at a ledge.

Stop here and belay on a ledge or lower off a set of anchors.

P2:

Climb broken and loose, lichen covered rock to the top and set a belay.
content.protection: A single set of cams and stoppers.
content.location:
The Passage

is the prominent corner/dihedral in the middle of the

Moore Wall

.

content.description:
Climb the left of the 2 crack that meet at the top of a pillar.  Get in the main crack and jam up the hand/fist crack to a roof.  Pop your body out of the crack and pull out the roof using tight hands to a 2 bolt anchor to the left of the crack.

One of the better hand cracks I have climbed in the Uintas
content.protection: Gear from .4 to #3 bd.  Doubles in hand size and 1 #4 is useful
content.location:
The hand crack between

Ray of Light

and

Mad Man of the Uintas

climbs.name: Mad Man of the Uinta's
climbs.fa: Shane Willet, Paul Moore, Mark Nakada. Summer 98

content.description: Start off with a HARD roof problem to a thin face.  From there is sweet face climbing on small crimp and side pulls.  Nice red point crux awaits towards the end.
content.protection: All bolts to bolted anchor.  I Recommend stick clipping the 2nd bolt
content.location: The bolted line between Of Mice and Men and the big corner system called The Passage.

content.description:
Free Passage starts with about 50' of dihedral crack

(The Passage, 5.7)

to a ledge where you might spot some webbing from days long gone. Make sure to use long runners on that first part, especially if you place gear in the dihedral above the ledge.

Continuing straight up would have you face rotten rock (that's

The Passage

); instead move up and right on the steep face using nice horizontals that eventually deposit you below a roof split by a hand crack maybe 10' left of the bolted

Don't Tell Jonny

.

Tackle the roof and enjoy another 30' of hands-to-finger goodness, eventually finding yourself in a blocky alcove. Scamper up and right out of this one to get to the chains.
content.protection:
Seems like a set of nuts and a single set of cams from BD #0 micro to BD #3 is sufficient. You could bring a #4 for the lower dihedral but the climbing is easy and the gear options plentiful.

I remember wishing for a second .75 at the roof but a #1 worked fine.

The horizontals gobble small cams, the upper crack swallows nuts.

Long runners are mandatory in the first half if you don't want rope drag to prevent any form of Passage.

Lower off - if I remember well - a newer 2 bolts + chains anchor. Or maybe some of those fat Metolius hangers...
content.location:
Free Passage climbs the first half of the massive dihedral that separates the south facing classics

(Don't Tell Johnny, Wish You Were Here)

from the rest of the more east-facing Moore Wall.

It eventually wanders on the steep S face after the halfway point.

content.description:
El Chapo is a new bolted route just right of Tequila.

70m rope required.

Scramble up to ledge and traverse right until below 1st bolt. Climb up face staying just right of Tequila crack until 1st roof. Make a few awkward moves left and clip 6th bolt/chain. The exciting and sequential crux demands good foot work to gain a sinker finger-lock. Continue past another roof and finish on easier terrain.
content.location:
Just right of Tequila crack.

Scramble up to ledge and traverse right to 1st bolt.

climbs.name: Don't Tell Jonny
climbs.fa: Shane Willet, Paul Moore, Mark Nakada 1998

content.description: Long crimpy face with some fun moves. Seems to get steeper the closer you get to the anchors.
content.location: Starts just a few feet right of the obvious corner crack.

content.description: A wonderful outing for any and all genders.
content.protection: 9 bolts (stainless 3/8" stud) to the thick rap hangers for Ray of Light.
content.location: Carefully nestled between Paul's Route and Ray of Light, start in a shallow corner on less than appealing rock.  After two clips you reach a bulge that marks the beginning of the nice climbing. Ascend upwards hence.
